posts.text: ChienI Kao ç­†è¨˜ç¶²ç«™ JHTNT ç­†è¨˜ç¶²ç«™ # å®‰è£ git - Windows git å®˜ç¶²: https://git-scm.com/download/win ç„¶å¾Œé–‹å•Ÿ Git Bash # è¨­å®š git è­˜åˆ¥è³‡æ–™ åœ¨ä½ å®‰è£ Git å¾Œé¦–å…ˆæ‡‰è©²åšçš„äº‹æ˜¯è¨­å®šä½¿ç”¨è€…åç¨±åŠé›»å­éƒµä»¶ã€‚ é€™ä¸€é»éå¸¸é‡è¦ï¼Œå› ç‚ºæ¯æ¬¡ Git çš„æäº¤æœƒä½¿ç”¨é€™äº›è³‡è¨Šï¼Œè€Œä¸”æäº¤å¾Œä¸èƒ½å†è¢«ä¿®æ”¹ã€‚ git config --global user.name "[ä½¿ç”¨è€…åå­—]"git config --global user.email "[é›»å­ä¿¡ç®±]"è‹¥ä½ æœ‰å‚³é --global åƒæ•¸ï¼Œåªéœ€è¦åšé€™å·¥ä½œä¸€æ¬¡ï¼Œå› ç‚ºåœ¨æ­¤ç³»çµ±ï¼Œä¸è«– Git åšä»»ä½•äº‹éƒ½æœƒæ¡ç”¨æ­¤è³‡è¨Šã€‚ # æª¢æŸ¥è®€è€…çš„è¨­å®š git config --list# å»ºç«‹å…¨æ–°çš„å„²å­˜åº« echo "# test" >> README.mdgit initgit add README.mdgit commit â€“m â€œfirst commitâ€git remote add origin [github_repository URL]git push â€“u origin main

posts.title: Git Information
posts.text: ChienI Kao ç­†è¨˜ç¶²ç«™ JHTNT ç­†è¨˜ç¶²ç«™ # å‰è¨€ ç‰ˆæœ¬æ§åˆ¶ç³»çµ±ï¼šå°è»Ÿé«”é–‹ç™¼éç¨‹ä¸­ç¨‹å¼ç¢¼ã€æ–‡ä»¶ã€æ–‡æª”ç­‰ï¼Œç™¼ç”Ÿçš„è®Šæ›´é€²è¡Œç®¡ç†çš„ç³»ç»Ÿï¼Œå®ƒå¯ä»¥å¹«åŠ©åœ˜éšŠæ›´å¥½çš„æºé€šå”ä½œï¼Œå¾è€Œæ›´å¥½çš„é€²è¡Œäº¤ä»˜ã€‚ å¸¸è¦‹çš„ç‰ˆæœ¬æ§åˆ¶ç³»çµ±åˆ†ç‚º: é›†ä¸­å¼ç‰ˆæœ¬æ§åˆ¶ç³»çµ±ï¼Œå¦‚: SVN ç”¨ä¸»å¾å¼æ¶æ§‹çš„ä½œæ³• éœ€è¦ç¶²è·¯æ‰å¯ä»¥å·¥ä½œï¼Œç‰ˆæœ¬åœ¨ä¸­å¤®æœå‹™å™¨ä¸Š åˆ†å¸ƒå¼ç‰ˆæœ¬æ§åˆ¶ç³»çµ± distributed version controlï¼Œå¦‚: Git å®ƒå…è¨±è»Ÿé«”é–‹ç™¼è€…å¯ä»¥å…±åŒåƒèˆ‡ä¸€å€‹è»Ÿé«”é–‹ç™¼å°ˆæ¡ˆï¼Œä½†æ˜¯ä¸å¿…åœ¨ç›¸åŒçš„ç¶²è·¯ç³»çµ±ä¸‹å·¥ä½œ ç”¨å°ç­‰ç¶²è·¯çš„ä½œæ³•ä¾†è™•ç†ç‰ˆæœ¬æ§åˆ¶ ç‰ˆæœ¬å­˜åœ¨è‡ªå·±çš„ host ä¸Šï¼ŒåŒæ™‚å‹•åˆ°ä¸€å€‹æª”æ¡ˆæ™‚ï¼Œäº’ç›¸çµ¦å°æ–¹çœ‹ï¼Œå› æ­¤è¡ä¼¸å‡ºé ç«¯æ•¸æ“šåº« å‰æƒ…æè¦: é€™ç« ä¸»è¦åœ¨ä»‹ç´¹ git æ˜¯ä»€éº¼ï¼Œä»¥åŠå…¶çš„ç”¨æ³•ï¼Œä¸¦ä»‹ç´¹ github ä¸€å€‹é ç«¯æ•¸æ“šåº«ã€‚ä¹Ÿæœƒæ¦‚è¿°ä¸€ä¸‹ git åˆ†æ”¯ï¼Œå¯ä»¥å¦‚ä½•ä½¿ç”¨ã€‚ # Git æ˜¯ä»€éº¼ï¼Ÿ Git æ˜¯ä¸€å€‹è»Ÿé«”ï¼Œå¯è—‰ç”±å®ƒç”¢ç”Ÿä¸€å€‹æ•¸æ“šåº«ï¼ˆrepositoryï¼‰ï¼Œä¸¦ä¸”åšåˆ°åˆ†æ•£å¼ç‰ˆæœ¬æ§åˆ¶ã€‚ ä»¥ä¸‹å¹¾å€‹åŠŸèƒ½è®“å”åŒé–‹ç™¼è®Šå¾—å®¹æ˜“ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚: å¤šè™•æ”¾ç½®åŒä¸€ä»½ç¨‹å¼ç¢¼ æ­·å²ç´€éŒ„è¿½è¹¤èˆ‡å›æœ” ç‰ˆæœ¬æ§åˆ¶ç³»çµ± (Version Control System) â€“ ç®¡ç†ä½ çš„ç¨‹å¼ç¢¼ç‰ˆæœ¬åæ‚”äº†å›å¾—å»ã€åˆä½µäº†èƒ½è™•ç†ã€å¤šäººå”ä½œäº’ä¸å¹²æ“¾ # GitHub æ˜¯ä»€éº¼ï¼Ÿ GitHub æ˜¯ä¸€å€‹é ç«¯æ•¸æ“šåº«ï¼Œå¯ç”¨æ–¼æª”æ¡ˆå­˜æ”¾ï¼Œä¸¦ç´€éŒ„æª”æ¡ˆç‰ˆæœ¬ï¼Œå°‡æœ¬åœ°ç«¯çš„æ•¸æ“šåº«å­˜æ–¼é ç«¯ï¼Œé”åˆ°å…±åŒé–‹ç™¼çš„ç›®çš„ã€‚ å¸¸è¦‹é ç«¯æ•¸æ“šåº« GitHub GitLab BitBucket # Git vs. GitHub? ä¸€å€‹æ˜¯å·¥å…·ï¼Œä¸€å€‹æ˜¯ç¶²ç«™ï¼ŒGitHub çš„æœ¬é«”æ˜¯ä¸€å€‹ Git Serverã€‚ # æ²’æœ‰ Git? ç•¶ä½ å¥½ä¸å®¹æ˜“å¯«å®Œç¨‹å¼ç¢¼ï¼Œå»è¢«ä½ çš„å¥½åŒäº‹ gankã€‚ğŸ˜¢

posts.title: 2622. Cache With Time Limit
posts.text: â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸ # é¡Œç›®æ•˜è¿° Write a class that allows getting and setting key-value pairs, however a time until expiration is associated with each key. The class has three public methods: set(key, value, duration) : accepts an integer key , an integer value , and a duration in milliseconds. Once the duration has elapsed, the key should be inaccessible. The method should return true if the same un-expired key already exists and false otherwise. Both the value and duration should be overwritten if the key already exists. get(key) : if an un-expired key exists, it should return the associated value. Otherwise it should return -1 . count() : returns the count of un-expired keys. # Example 1: Input: ["TimeLimitedCache", "set", "get", "count", "get"] [[], [1, 42, 100], [1], [], [1]] [0, 0, 50, 50, 150] Output: [null, false, 42, 1, -1] Explanation: At t=0, the cache is constructed. At t=0, a key-value pair (1: 42) is added with a time limit of 100ms. The value doesn't exist so false is returned. At t=50, key=1 is requested and the value of 42 is returned. At t=50, count() is called and there is one active key in the cache. At t=100, key=1 expires. At t=150, get(1) is called but -1 is returned because the cache is empty. # Example 2: Input: ["TimeLimitedCache", "set", "set", "get", "get", "get", "count"] [[], [1, 42, 50], [1, 50, 100], [1], [1], [1], []] [0, 0, 40, 50, 120, 200, 250] Output: [null, false, true, 50, 50, -1] Explanation: At t=0, the cache is constructed. At t=0, a key-value pair (1: 42) is added with a time limit of 50ms. The value doesn't exist so false is returned. At t=40, a key-value pair (1: 50) is added with a time limit of 100ms. A non-expired value already existed so true is returned and the old value was overwritten. At t=50, get(1) is called which returned 50. At t=120, get(1) is called which returned 50. At t=140, key=1 expires. At t=200, get(1) is called but the cache is empty so -1 is returned. At t=250, count() returns 0 because the cache is empty. # è§£é¡Œæ€è·¯ # Solution var TimeLimitedCache = function() { this.cache = new Map();};/** * @param {number} key * @param {number} value * @param {number} time until expiration in ms * @return {boolean} if un-expired key already existed */TimeLimitedCache.prototype.set = function(key, value, duration) { const val = this.cache.get(key); if(val){ clearTimeout(val.timeout); } const timeout = setTimeout(() => this.cache.delete(key), duration); this.cache.set(key, {value, timeout}); return Boolean(val);};/** * @param {number} key * @return {number} value associated with key */TimeLimitedCache.prototype.get = function(key) { return this.cache.has(key) ? this.cache.get(key).value : -1;};/** * @return {number} count of non-expired keys */TimeLimitedCache.prototype.count = function() { return this.cache.size;};/** * Your TimeLimitedCache object will be instantiated and called as such: * var obj = new TimeLimitedCache() * obj.set(1, 42, 1000); // false * obj.get(1) // 42 * obj.count() // 1 */ class TimeLimitedCache { cache: Map<any, any>; constructor() { this.cache = new Map(); } set(key: number, value: number, duration: number): boolean { const val: any = this.cache.get(key); if (val) { clearTimeout(val.timeout); } const timeout = setTimeout((): Boolean => this.cache.delete(key), duration); this.cache.set(key, { value, timeout }); return Boolean(val); } get(key: number): number { return this.cache.has(key) ? this.cache.get(key).value : -1; } count(): number { return this.cache.size; }}/** * Your TimeLimitedCache object will be instantiated and called as such: * var obj = new TimeLimitedCache() * obj.set(1, 42, 1000); // false * obj.get(1) // 42 * obj.count() // 1 */ å–®å­— ** ** !! !! ç‰‡èª & æ­é…è© !! !!

posts.title: 1557. Minimum Number of Vertices to Reach All Nodes
posts.text: â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸ # é¡Œç›®æ•˜è¿° Given a directed acyclic graph, with n vertices numbered from 0 to n - 1 , and an array edges where edges[i] = [fromi, toi] represents a directed edge from node fromi to node toi . Find the smallest set of vertices from which all nodes in the graph are reachable. It's guaranteed that a unique solution exists. Notice that you can return the vertices in any order. # Example 1: Input: n = 6, edges = [[0,1],[0,2],[2,5],[3,4],[4,2]] Output: [0,3] Explanation: It's not possible to reach all the nodes from a single vertex. From 0 we can reach [0,1,2,5]. From 3 we can reach [3,4,2,5]. So we output [0,3]. # Example 2: Input: n = 5, edges = [[0,1],[2,1],[3,1],[1,4],[2,4]] Output: [0,2,3] Explanation: Notice that vertices 0, 3 and 2 are not reachable from any other node, so we must include them. Also any of these vertices can reach nodes 1 and 4. # è§£é¡Œæ€è·¯ # Solution import java.util.ArrayList;import java.util.HashSet;import java.util.List;import java.util.Set;class Solution { public List<Integer> findSmallestSetOfVertices(int n, List<List<Integer>> edges) { Set<Integer> link = new HashSet<>(); for (List<Integer> edge : edges) { link.add(edge.get(1)); } List<Integer> ans = new ArrayList<>(); for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) { if (!link.contains(i)) { ans.add(i); } } return ans; }} å–®å­— ** ** !! !! ç‰‡èª & æ­é…è© !! !!

posts.title: 2636. Promise Pool
posts.text: â­ï¸ # é¡Œç›®æ•˜è¿° Given an array of asyncronous functions functions and a pool limit n , return an asyncronous function promisePool . It should return a promise that resolves when all the input functions resolve. Pool limit is defined as the maximum number promises that can be pending at once. promisePool should begin execution of as many functions as possible and continue executing new functions when old promises resolve. promisePool should execute functions[i] then functions[i + 1] then functions[i + 2] , etc. When the last promise resolves, promisePool should also resolve. For example, if n = 1 , promisePool will execute one function at a time in series. However, if n = 2 , it first executes two functions. When either of the two functions resolve, a 3rd function should be executed (if available), and so on until there are no functions left to execute. You can assume all functions never reject. It is acceptable for promisePool to return a promise that resolves any value. # Example 1: Input: functions = [ () => new Promise(res => setTimeout(res, 300)), () => new Promise(res => setTimeout(res, 400)), () => new Promise(res => setTimeout(res, 200)) ] n = 2 Output: [[300,400,500],500] Explanation: Three functions are passed in. They sleep for 300ms, 400ms, and 200ms respectively. They resolve at 300ms, 400ms, and 500ms respectively. The returned promise resolves at 500ms. At t=0, the first 2 functions are executed. The pool size limit of 2 is reached. At t=300, the 1st function resolves, and the 3rd function is executed. Pool size is 2. At t=400, the 2nd function resolves. There is nothing left to execute. Pool size is 1. At t=500, the 3rd function resolves. Pool size is zero so the returned promise also resolves. # Example 2: Input: functions = [ () => new Promise(res => setTimeout(res, 300)), () => new Promise(res => setTimeout(res, 400)), () => new Promise(res => setTimeout(res, 200)) ] n = 5 Output: [[300,400,200],400] Explanation: The three input promises resolve at 300ms, 400ms, and 200ms respectively. The returned promise resolves at 400ms. At t=0, all 3 functions are executed. The pool limit of 5 is never met. At t=200, the 3rd function resolves. Pool size is 2. At t=300, the 1st function resolved. Pool size is 1. At t=400, the 2nd function resolves. Pool size is 0, so the returned promise also resolves. # Example 3: Input: functions = [ () => new Promise(res => setTimeout(res, 300)), () => new Promise(res => setTimeout(res, 400)), () => new Promise(res => setTimeout(res, 200)) ] n = 1 Output: [[300,700,900],900] Explanation: The three input promises resolve at 300ms, 700ms, and 900ms respectively. The returned promise resolves at 900ms. At t=0, the 1st function is executed. Pool size is 1. At t=300, the 1st function resolves and the 2nd function is executed. Pool size is 1. At t=700, the 2nd function resolves and the 3rd function is executed. Pool size is 1. At t=900, the 3rd function resolves. Pool size is 0 so the returned promise resolves. # è§£é¡Œæ€è·¯ # Solution /** * @param {Function[]} functions * @param {number} n * @return {Function} */var promisePool = async function (functions, n) { const nextPromise = async function next() { if (functions.length == 0){ return ; } const fn = functions.shift(); await fn(); await next(); } const ans = Array(n).fill(null).map(nextPromise); return await Promise.all(ans);};/** * const sleep = (t) => new Promise(res => setTimeout(res, t)); * promisePool([() => sleep(500), () => sleep(400)], 1) * .then(console.log) // After 900ms */ type F = () => Promise<any>;function promisePool(functions: F[], n: number): Promise<any> { const nextPromise = async function next():Promise<any> { if(functions.length == 0){ return ; } const fn: Function = functions.shift(); await fn(); await next(); } const ans: Promise<any>[] = Array(n).fill(null).map(nextPromise); return Promise.all(ans);};/** * const sleep = (t) => new Promise(res => setTimeout(res, t)); * promisePool([() => sleep(500), () => sleep(400)], 1) * .then(console.log) // After 900ms */ å–®å­— ** ** !! !! ç‰‡èª & æ­é…è© !! !!

posts.title: 2130. Maximum Twin Sum of a Linked List
posts.text: â­ï¸â­ï¸â­ï¸ # é¡Œç›®æ•˜è¿° In a linked list of size n , where n is even, the ith node (0-indexed) of the linked list is known as the twin of the (n-1-i)th node, if 0 <= i <= (n / 2) - 1 . For example, if n = 4 , then node 0 is the twin of node 3 , and node 1 is the twin of node 2 . These are the only nodes with twins for n = 4 . The twin sum is defined as the sum of a node and its twin. Given the head of a linked list with even length, return the maximum twin sum of the linked list. # Example 1: Input: head = [5,4,2,1] Output: 6 Explanation: Nodes 0 and 1 are the twins of nodes 3 and 2, respectively. All have twin sum = 6. There are no other nodes with twins in the linked list. Thus, the maximum twin sum of the linked list is 6. # Example 2: Input: head = [4,2,2,3] Output: 7 Explanation: The nodes with twins present in this linked list are: Node 0 is the twin of node 3 having a twin sum of 4 + 3 = 7. Node 1 is the twin of node 2 having a twin sum of 2 + 2 = 4. Thus, the maximum twin sum of the linked list is max(7, 4) = 7. # Example 3: ![](https://assets.leetcode.com/uploads/2021/12/03/eg3drawio.png =300x) Input: head = [1,100000] Output: 100001 Explanation: There is only one node with a twin in the linked list having twin sum of 1 + 100000 = 100001. # è§£é¡Œæ€è·¯ # Solution // Definition for singly-linked list.import java.util.Deque;import java.util.LinkedList;public class ListNode { int val; ListNode next; ListNode() {} ListNode(int val) { this.val = val; } ListNode(int val, ListNode next) { this.val = val; this.next = next; }} class Solution { public int pairSum(ListNode head) { Deque<Integer> dq = new LinkedList<>(); ListNode curr = new ListNode(); curr = head; while(curr != null){ dq.add(curr.val); curr = curr.next; } int max = Integer.MIN_VALUE; while(!dq.isEmpty() && dq.size() >= 2){ max = Math.max(max, dq.pollFirst() + dq.pollLast()); } return max; }} å–®å­— ** ** !! !! ç‰‡èª & æ­é…è© !! !!

listen [::]:80 default_server; server_name _; root /usr/share/nginx/html; index index.html; charset utf-8; access_log /var/log/nginx/access_log; error_log /var/log/nginx/error_log; } å…§å®¹ç´°ç¯€èªªæ˜å¯ä»¥å»çœ‹ docker practise - 1ï¼Œé‚£é‚Šæœ‰ç¨å¾®èªªæ˜ä¸€ä¸‹å…§å®¹æ¶µæ„ã€‚ # å‰µå»ºä¸€å€‹ Dockerfile çš„æª”æ¡ˆ å‰µå»ºä¸€å€‹ Dockerfile æª”ï¼Œæ²’æœ‰å‰¯æª”åï¼Œç´”æª”æ¡ˆã€‚ Dockerfile å…§å®¹å¦‚ä¸‹: FROM nginxMAINTAINER HsingYu# è¤‡è£½ä¸€æ•´å€‹åœ¨æ ¹ç›®éŒ„å°ˆæ¡ˆçš„æª”æ¡ˆé€²å»COPY / /usr/share/nginx/html# å¦‚æœåªæœ‰ä¸€å€‹æª”æ¡ˆï¼Œå¦‚: index.html å¯ä»¥å¯« # COPY index.html /usr/share/nginx/html# æŠŠ nignx.conf åŠ å…¥é è¨­ conf è£¡é¢COPY nginx.conf /etc/nginx/conf.d/default.conf# å®¹å™¨å°å¤–é€£æ¥ 80 portEXPOSE 80é€™æ¨£å°±å®Œæˆæ’°å¯« Dockerfile äº†ã€‚ # åˆ©ç”¨ Dockerfile å»ºç«‹ images docker bulid -t ["images name"] . -t : å¾Œé¢æ¥ç‚º images å‘½åçš„åç¨±ï¼Œæ³¨æ„ä¸å¯ä»¥æ˜¯å¤§å¯«å­—æ¯ï¼Œè¦æ˜¯å°å¯«å–”ï½ï½ . : æŒ‡åœ¨é€™å€‹åœ°æ–¹ä¸‹çš„ Dockerfile å»ºç«‹å®Œæˆæœƒå¦‚ä¸‹åœ–: # åŸ·è¡Œå»ºç«‹çš„ images docker run -p 80:80 ["images name"] -p : å¾Œé¢å¯«é€šä¿¡çš„ port 80:80 : ç‚ºäº†æ–¹ä¾¿å€åˆ†å†’è™Ÿ (:) å‰å¾Œ port ä»£è¡¨çš„ä¸åŒæ„æ€ï¼Œæ¥ä¸‹ä¾†æœƒä»¥ 8080:80 ä¾†è§£é‡‹ï¼Œå®¹å™¨å°‡åœ¨ç«¯å£ 8080 ä¸Šçš„ä¸»æ©Ÿä¸Šå¯ç”¨ï¼Œä½†å®ƒèˆ‡ç«¯å£ 80 ä¸Šçš„å®¹å™¨ï¼ˆå’Œæ‡‰ç”¨ç¨‹åºï¼‰é€šä¿¡ï¼Œç°¡å–®ä¾†èªªå°±æ˜¯åœ¨ bowser ä¸­è¼¸å…¥å®¹å™¨é‹è¡Œæ‰€åœ¨çš„ Docker ä¸»æ©Ÿçš„ DNS åç¨±æˆ–è€… IP ä½å€ï¼Œä¸¦åœ¨å¾Œé¢åŠ ä¸Š port 8080ï¼Œä¾‹å¦‚: localhost:8080 åŸ·è¡ŒæˆåŠŸæœƒå¦‚ä¸‹åœ–: localhost port 80 ä¸ç”¨ç‰¹åˆ¥å¯«ï¼Œlocalhost:80 => localhost

posts.text: # Docker Compose # ç‚ºä»€éº¼è¦ç”¨ Docker Compose? ä¹‹å‰æœ‰ä»‹ç´¹éä½¿ç”¨ docker run æŒ‡ä»¤å°±å¯ä»¥æŠŠ Docker Container å•Ÿå‹•èµ·ä¾†ï¼Œä½†æ˜¯å¦‚æœæˆ‘å€‘è¦å•Ÿå‹•å¾ˆå¤šå€‹ Docker Container æ™‚ï¼Œå°±éœ€è¦è¼¸å…¥å¾ˆå¤šæ¬¡ docker run æŒ‡ä»¤ã€‚ å¦å¤– container å’Œ container ä¹‹é–“è¦åšé—œè¯çš„è©±ä¹Ÿè¦è¨˜å¾—å®ƒå€‘ä¹‹é–“è¦å¦‚ä½•çš„é€£çµ (link) Containerï¼Œé€™æ¨£åœ¨è¦å•Ÿå‹•å¤šå€‹ Container çš„æƒ…æ³ä¸‹ï¼Œå°±æœƒé¡¯å¾—æ¯”è¼ƒéº»ç…©ã€‚ # å¦‚ä½•é‹ä½œï¼Ÿ Docker-Compose: å¯«ä¸€å€‹ docker-compose.yml ï¼ŒæŠŠæ‰€æœ‰è¦ä½¿ç”¨ Docker Image å¯«ä¸Šå»ï¼Œä¹Ÿå¯ä»¥æŠŠ Container ä¹‹é–“çš„é—œä¿‚é€£çµ (link) èµ·ä¾†ã€‚ æœ€å¾Œåªè¦ä¸‹ docker-compose up æŒ‡ä»¤ï¼Œå°±å¯ä»¥æŠŠæ‰€æœ‰çš„ Docker Container åŸ·è¡Œèµ·ä¾†ï¼Œé€™æ¨£å°±å¯ä»¥å¾ˆå¿«é€Ÿå’Œæ–¹ä¾¿çš„å•Ÿå‹•å¤šå€‹ containerã€‚ # Docker Compose å¸¸ç”¨æŒ‡ä»¤ # å•Ÿå‹•æ‰€æœ‰çš„ Docker Container $ docker-compose up # æŸ¥çœ‹ Docker Container çš„åŸ·è¡Œç‹€æ…‹ $ docker-compose ps # çœ‹åŸ·è¡Œçš„ log $ docker-compose logs # åœæ­¢ docker-compose åŸ·è¡Œçš„æ‰€æœ‰ Container $ docker-compose stop # åˆªé™¤ docker-compose çš„æ‰€æœ‰ Container $ docker-compose rm # Docker Compose å¯¦ä½œ å¯¦ä½œçš„éƒ¨ä»½ä¸»è¦å°±æ˜¯è¦æŠŠ Docker-Compose å®‰è£èµ·ä¾† ç„¶å¾Œæ’°å¯«ä¸€å€‹ docker-compose.yml ä¸¦ä¸”ä½¿ç”¨ docker-compose up ï¼ŒæŒ‡ä»¤æŠŠæ‰€æœ‰çš„ Docker Container å•Ÿå‹•èµ·ä¾† # å®‰è£ Docker-Compose # cd /usr/bin # wget https://github.com/docker/compose/releases/download/1.18.0/docker-compose-Linux-x86_64 # mv docker-compose-Linux-x86_64 docker-compose # chmod 755 docker-compose # æ’°å¯« docker-compose.yml version: '2' services: db: image: mysql environment: MYSQL_ROOT_PASSWORD: 123456 admin: image: adminer ports: - posts.text: # Dockerfile Dockerfile ç”±ä¸€è¡Œè¡Œå‘½ä»¤èªå¥çµ„æˆï¼Œä¸¦ä¸”æ”¯æ´ä»¥ # é–‹é ­çš„è¨»è§£è¡Œã€‚ Dockerfile åˆ†ç‚ºå››éƒ¨åˆ†ï¼š åŸºåº•æ˜ åƒæª”è³‡è¨Š ç¶­è­·è€…è³‡è¨Š æ˜ åƒæª”æ“ä½œæŒ‡ä»¤ å®¹å™¨å•Ÿå‹•æ™‚åŸ·è¡ŒæŒ‡ä»¤ã€‚ # This dockerfile uses the ubuntu image # VERSION 2 - EDITION 1 # Author: docker_user # Command format: Instruction [arguments / command] .. # åŸºæœ¬æ˜ åƒæª”ï¼Œå¿…é ˆæ˜¯ç¬¬ä¸€å€‹æŒ‡ä»¤ FROM ubuntu# ç¶­è­·è€…ï¼š docker_user <docker_user at email.com> (@docker_user) MAINTAINER docker_user docker_user@email.com # æ›´æ–°æ˜ åƒæª”çš„æŒ‡ä»¤ RUN echo "deb http://archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu/ raring main universe" >> /etc/apt/sources.list RUN apt-get update && apt-get install -y nginx RUN echo "\ndaemon off;" >> /etc/nginx/nginx.conf #
